This vote represents whether I want to further enable a Speaker who has hurt our country, damaged our democracy, and threatened the financial security of Virginians for political gain.

In the absence of any desire by Speaker McCarthy to focus on governing, my answer is no. (7/7)
Speaker McCarthy’s lack of leadership has not only threatened America’s economy and national security, but it has imperiled his own speakership. (6/7)

Each time, I implored him to demonstrate leadership, bring forth bipartisan bills, and not bend to the will of his extreme right wing.

Unfortunately, he has coddled this faction — and the American people have suffered. (5/7)

Again last week, he brought us to the brink of a shutdown before he was willing to acknowledge that a bipartisan solution — and the votes of 209 House Democrats — would be necessary to protect the function of our government and the livelihoods of the Virginians I serve. (4/7)

Speaker McCarthy brought America to the brink of a debt crisis long before he was willing to acknowledge that a bipartisan solution — and the votes of House Democrats — would be necessary to protect our economy. (3/7)

In the short time that Speaker McCarthy has been at the helm, he has threatened our economic stability, our position of global leadership, and the financial security of the thousands of federal employees, servicemembers, small businesses, and contractors I represent. (2/7)

My full statement on today’s vote on the Motion to Vacate:

The American people — and the people of Virginia’s Seventh District — deserve a Congress that functions. (1/7)

Congress has until November 17 to avert a government shutdown that would leave thousands of federal contractors with reduced working hours or without pay.

That’s why I helped lead a bill to guarantee that contractors are compensated for wages and benefits lost during shutdowns.

We need to work in a bipartisan way to get these priorities across the finish line, and as the Representative of thousands of federal employees, servicemembers, and contractors, we need to take steps to avoid these Groundhog Day funding crises in the future.
Going forward, Congress has a long to-do list — including passing the 2023 Farm Bill, supporting our allies in Ukraine, and once again avoiding a government shutdown.
As a country, we need to get back to the basics of governing — recognizing our shared challenges, hammering out differences, and finding a responsible compromise that averts disaster.

Speaker McCarthy rewarded this behavior for far too long — even though a bipartisan solution was clearly on the table to keep America’s government open.

We need to move away — sharply — from the idea that being an elected official means a blank checkbook to grandstand.

Many of my colleagues in the House GOP refused to listen to these voices.

They were determined to bring down the very functioning of America’s government for the sake of raising money, grabbing headlines, and getting the attention they so desperately crave.

We should never have come this close to a government shutdown.

For days, thousands of Virginians feared being forced to work without pay, being furloughed, or struggling to make ends meet.

For months, businesses sounded the alarm about the devastating effects of shutdowns.

If our federal employees, servicemembers, and contractors won't get paid during a shutdown, neither should Members of Congress.

That's why I’ve asked the U.S. House to withhold my pay until Congress is able to work together to fund the government.

If the House GOP majority forces a government shutdown, lawmakers would still draw a paycheck.

Hardworking Virginians like Marie would not.

I'm leading the charge to block congressional pay in the event of a shutdown — because Marie is right.

The rules aren't fair.

(2) Encouraging my colleagues to support my bipartisan bill to prohibit lawmakers from getting paid in the event of a shutdown. If Americans and local businesses that work in support of our nation don’t get paid during shutdowns, neither should their representatives in Congress!

(1) Ringing the alarm bells early in advance of September 30 — the end of the fiscal year — about the risk of a shutdown. The Republican-led House of Representatives must follow the lead of the Senate and pass BIPARTISAN funding bills; and
Because the livelihoods of Americans and the very function of our government must never be used as a political bargaining chip, I am taking two actions now:

Notably absent from the long list of those financially impacted by a shutdown are Members of Congress.

Shutdown = Congress still gets paid.

It’s as shocking as it's inappropriate — but it explains why some in Congress are willing to gamble with other people’s paychecks.
The antics of some in the House of Representatives are risking the ability of Congress to execute on one of our most foundational jobs — funding the function of our government.

A shutdown threatens the very function of our government — making it harder to reach the Social Security Administration, closing Veterans Benefits Administration public contact services, and exacerbating existing claims backlogs.

But the consequences go beyond financial.

The FAA is already contending with a shortage of air traffic controllers.

The last time the government shut down, so did their training academy.

A shutdown would set us even further back in keeping flights operating safely.

Consider government contractors, restaurant workers near government facilities, and small business owners across Virginia’s Seventh District.

These Americans and businesses never get paid back the revenue lost during a shutdown.

For our nation’s public servants who protect our borders and our nation’s security or for those who deliver Social Security and Veterans benefits, knowing you will likely get paid back in a few weeks does not keep food on the table for your family.
The impact was so severe that federal prison guards told me harrowing stories of working unpaid in the federal prison system.

The impact was so severe that local community members were donating gas cards to TSA employees who (after missed paychecks) couldn’t afford the gas they needed to get to work — where they were working (without a paycheck in sight) to keep our air travel safe.

In 2019, I was sworn into Congress during the longest government shutdown in history.

The impact was so severe that there were special hours at the local food bank to accommodate federal employees.

As a former federal employee, I know that is often true.

But it does not change the fact that far too many Americans, including federal employees, live paycheck to paycheck.

A government shutdown would be devastating for so many American workers.

Thousands of federal workers will be furloughed or work without pay.

But I’ll sometimes hear colleagues take this consequence lightly — “In the end, they get paid back.”

TL;DR: A government shutdown would be a disgrace.

I represent thousands of Virginia federal employees.

And as I hear from the GOP majority that a shutdown is not only possible, but not of concern, I'm ringing the alarm to make sure everyone knows why a shutdown is unacceptable.

Our Public Safety Healthcare Retirees Act would increase the pre-tax distribution public safety officers can use from their pension plan to $6,000.

Thank you @RepBrianFitz, @RepDanKildee, and @RepDonBacon for your leadership in this effort.

As part of the Pension Protection Act, Congress included a provision that allows retired police officers and firefighters to withdraw $3,000 tax-free from their pension plan each year to pay healthcare or long-term care premiums.

But this amount has not increased since 2006.

Many police officers and firefighters retire early — years from Medicare eligibility — due to the demands of the job.

That’s why I introduced a bipartisan bill to raise the value of a key tax benefit for retirees in Virginia and across our country to cover medical expenses.

American taxpayers deserve to feel confident that their money is being put to good use — not ending up in the wrong hands.
